section.title: If structures (2)
section.sectiontitle: If structures or conditional sentences generally have two clauses: the 'if' clause and the result clause. The if clause can come first or second. When the if clause is first, we need a comma at the end of the clause.
section.text1a: If you leave now, you might get there in time.
section.text2a: You might get there in time if you leave now.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Zero Conditional to talk about things that always happen. Use the present simple in the 'If' clause and the result clause.

section.title: If structures (2)
section.sectiontitle: Use the First Conditional to talk about future possibility. Use the Present Simple, Present Continuous or Present Perfect in the if clause. Use will, Present Continuous, Imperative or going to in the result clause.
section.text1a: If you're going to the party tomorrow, I'll see you there.
section.text2a: If you take the tablets, drink plenty of water.
section.sectiontitle2: We can also use modal verbs could / should / might / may in the result clause.
section.text3a: If you leave now, you might get there in time.
section.text4a: If you go in summer, you should get good weather.

section.title: If structures (2)
section.sectiontitle: Use the Second Conditional to talk about present or future unreal or imagined situations. Use the Past Simple or Past Continuous in the if clause. Use would / could / should / might + infinitive in the result clause.
section.text1a: If there was a gym near them, they might do more exercise.
section.text2a: He would be much healthier if he didn't smoke.
section.sectiontitle2: Use the Third Conditional to talk about past unreal situations with a past result. Use the Past Perfect in the if clause. Use would have, could have, should have or might have + past participle in the result clause.
section.text3a: If you hadn't been so rude, he wouldn't have walked out.
section.text4a: I could have gone to the party if I'd known about it.

section.title: If structures (2)
section.sectiontitle: There is a Mixed Conditional form where the if clause refers to the past and the result clause refers to the present or future. Use the Past Perfect in the if clause. Use would (or 'd) + infinitive in the result clause.
section.text1a: If we hadn't missed the plane, we'd be in Spain now.
section.text2a: If they had known about the traffic, they wouldn't be in the car.
section.sectiontitle2: There is also a Mixed Conditional form where the if clause refers to the present or future and the result clause refers to the past.
section.text3a: If you didn't want to come to the theatre tomorrow, I wouldn't have bothered getting you a ticket.
section.text4a: If I didn't have a computer, I wouldn't have bought that expensive software.

section.title: If structures (2)
section.sectiontitle: We can use modals in the First and Second conditionals.
section.text1a: If you see James, you should invite him to the party.
section.text2a: If I went to university, I could study engineering.
section.sectiontitle2: We can use modals in the Third and Mixed conditionals.
section.text3a: If I had studied harder, I might have passed my exam.
section.text4a: If I'd applied for that job, I could be earning a lot of money now.
